@civeljahim Logically and linguistically equivalent! We'd say "couldn't care less" to be brusque and rude, and "could care more" to be gently sarcastic. Same meaning, different tone.
@civeljahim I particularly wince at the crazy US expression "I could care less", whereas it's logically "I couldn't care less", as we say here.

@civeljahim We would never say "yes" to mean "go ahead" or "do as you wish" here; it means the opposite, and would be very impolite. We'd instead explicitly say "please do" or similar. Perhaps different in US, where many expressions are butchered into illogicality!
@iChris Well that's a fine perspective indeed.

In English, there's a colloquial use of the word "cross" in the UK to mean "irritated" or "angry".
Examples: I'm feeling cross. She was cross with me.
